greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of connectedness systems covering n vertices without singletons.
comment: We define a connectedness system (investigated by Vim van Dam in 2002) to be a set of finite nonempty sets (edges) that is closed under taking the union of any two overlapping edges. It is covering if every vertex belongs to some edge.
link: Gus Wiseman, Every Clutter Is a Tree of Blobs, The Mathematica Journal, Vol. 19, 2017.
example: The a(3) = 8 covering connectedness systems without singletons:
xref: Inverse binomial transform of A072446 (the non-covering case).
Exponential transform of A072447 if we assume A072447(1) = 0 (the connected case).
The case with singletons is A326870.
The BII-numbers of these set-systems are A326873.
results.author: _Gus Wiseman_, Jul 30 2019
